column1: A habitat is an ecological or environmental area that is inhabited by a particular species of animal
column3: or other type of organism. The term typically refers to the zone in which the organism lives and where it can find food
column5: protection and mates for reproduction. It is the natural environment in which an organism lives
column6: or the physical environment that surrounds a species population.A habitat is made up of physical factors such as soil
column9: and light intensity as well as biotic factors such as the availability of food and the presence or absence of predators. Every organism has certain habitat needs for the conditions in which it will thrive
column10: but some are tolerant of wide variations while others are very specific in their requirements. A habitat is not necessarily a geographical area
column11: it can be the interior of a stem
column13: a rock or a clump of moss
column14: and for a parasitic organism it is the body of its host
column15: part of the host's body such as the digestive tract
column16: or a single cell within the host's body.
